media:content.media:description: WOODLAND HILLS, CA - MAY 09: A mountain biker wearing a mask at Upper Las Virgenes Canyon Open Space Preserve takes advantage of newly reopened trails Saturday, May 9, 2020 in Woodland Hills, CA. Masks were mandatory but only around half of the people were wearing them. A park ranger was warning people to wear their masks, yet another park ranger who was ticketing nearby cars without permits, was not wearing one herself. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: As demand for food skyrockets due to coronavirus, food banks play catch-up
item.dc:creator: Esmeralda Bermudez
item.description: The need for food in L.A. County has reached record levels, putting food banks under pressure to deliver even while their normal supply chains are disrupted.
item.content:encoded: The need for food in L.A. County has reached record levels, putting food banks under pressure to deliver even while their normal supply chains are disrupted.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 06: Volunteer Nina Forbess gives baby food to a grateful Monica Alcazar in the vehicle with 19-year-old daughter Miriam Alcazar at St. Margaret's Center Catholic Charities of Los Angeles as close to 300 families line up now each Wednesday to collect food at a drive-thru and walk-up pantry. The need for food has reached record levels in L.A. County and food banks are hustling to keep up. The Los Angeles Regional Food Bank has gone from serving 300,000 families to to 500,00 families per month. Some are now having to purchase or compete for food as supplies are running slow or they are struggling with a shortage of volunteers. Downtown on Wednesday, May 6, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: One man's quest to document the Westside's homeless and hold officials accountable

item.content:encoded: Semi-retired in Westwood, he'd rather stay at home, but begins each day taking a homeless tent census.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 07: Don Wood observes a new growing homeless encampment outside the fences of the Los Angeles National Veterans Park as he follows a regular route touring homeless encampments on the Los Angeles Westside. Wearing a mask and practicing social distancing because of the Coronavirus Covid-19 there are about six encampment sites he checks every day. Westwood on Thursday, May 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Teen volunteers organize service to help most vulnerable during coronavirus outbreak
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: Volunteers from six Santa Clarita Valley high schools step forward to help those shut in by the COVID-19 pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Volunteers from six Santa Clarita Valley high schools step forward to help those shut in by the COVID-19 pandemic.

media:content.media:description: *DO NOT USE UNTIL KEVIN BAXTER STORY RUNS* VALENCIA, CA - MAY 05, 2020 - - Christine Riel, 16, left, and Krysta Mendoza, 17, juniors at West Ranch High School , fill an online grocery order from the site, sixfeetsupplies.com at an Albertson's store in Valencia on May 5, 2020. The students shop for homebound people, who are not just seniors, but anyone who needs help. The work is completely voluntary and the students are not paid. Six Feet Supplies, which takes its name from the separation required by social distancing, has more than 100 volunteers delivering food to a dozen homes a day, serving the homeless and manning a telephone help line for people who just need to talk. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Coronavirus infections explode at a Lompoc federal prison with 792 testing positive, making it the largest federal penitentiary outbreak in the nation.

media:content.media:description: The Federal Correctional Institution in Lompoc, Calif., is shown in a Dec. 1995 photo. The prison, which houses low to medium security inmates, is on the same grounds as the Lompoc Federal Prison Camp, where former Gov., Fife Symington would likely serve his sentence. Symington resigned in disgrace Sept. 3, 1997, after a federal jury convicted him of defrauding lenders during his former career as a real estate developer. ( AP Photo/Santa Maria Times, Jeffrey May)

(Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California slowly reopens as stores offer curbside pickup. Will it be enough to keep businesses afloat?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Gomez, Andrew J. Campa, Hailey Branson-Potts, Ruben Vives
item.description: California's tepid reopening amid the coronavirus sparked a mix of excitement, confusion and uncertainty.
item.content:encoded: California's tepid reopening amid the coronavirus sparked a mix of excitement, confusion and uncertainty.

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA - MAY 07, 2020 - - Salt women's clothing store owner Holly Boies, 53, right, talks with longtime shopper Enid Koffler at the front door of her store on Abbott Kinney Blvd. in Venice on May 7, 2020. Boies is is planning to open her store for curbside pick-up tomorrow. "We'll see how it goes. I'll be here," Boies said about opening her business for curbside pick-up. She's really struggling. She's owned the clothing store on Abbott Kinney for the past 17 years. Her landlord is cutting her some slack right now on paying rent and she's waiting for an SBA loan. She's applied for unemployment for a small business loan and but does not qualify for a PPP loan because she is the sole person who runs the store. Retail businesses, such as book stores, clothing stores, toy stores and florists, can reopen for curbside pickup starting Friday. In order to do so, they are being asked to develop contactless payment procedures, have hand sanitizer available for employees and customers, ensure employees have proper protective gear, and ask employees to deliver goods to customers' cars when possible. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

Gavin Newsom speaks at the California Legislative Black Caucus Martin Luther King Jr., Breakfast in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom's administration is using a new law for the first time in an attempt to force Southern California's self-styled "Surf City USA" to meet housing goals. item.title: What will concerts look like when California reopens?
item.dc:creator: August Brown, Randall Roberts, Mikael Wood
item.description: California is slowly reopening, providing hope that you might soon see your favorite artist in concert. But from an arena stage? A computer screen? A drive-in?
item.content:encoded: Even in the most optimistic future under COVID-19, live music will be one of the last things to return to normal. When it does — and it will eventually — shows will be profoundly different. Beloved venues may have closed for good, crowds will be wary of each other on dancefloors and digital life may have supplanted sweaty clubs and sunny festival fields.Since The Times started documenting the fallout of COVID-19 for the music industry, the news has often been dire. The concert business is decimated for now, and everyone from wedding bands to record store clerks are terrified of the next few months. But public health experts believe there is a path forward to return eventually. Artists have turned to livestreaming in ingenious, sometimes hilarious ways to stay afloat (and sane). Music, as always, finds a way to be heard.We hear from readers every day about how much they miss the heartbeat of L.A. nightlife. Until it returns in all its close-quartered, ear-splitting glory, just imagine how good that first cold drink on a hot festival field will taste. We'll get back there someday.

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA - MAY 07, 2020 - - Salt women's clothing store owner Holly Boies, 53, right, talks with longtime shopper Enid Koffler at the front door of her store on Abbott Kinney Blvd. in Venice on May 7, 2020. Boies is is planning to open her store for curbside pick-up tomorrow. "We'll see how it goes. I'll be here," Boies said about opening her business for curbside pick-up. She's really struggling. She's owned the clothing store on Abbott Kinney for the past 17 years. Her landlord is cutting her some slack right now on paying rent and she's waiting for an SBA loan. She's applied for unemployment for a small business loan and but does not qualify for a PPP loan because she is the sole person who runs the store. Retail businesses, such as book stores, clothing stores, toy stores and florists, can reopen for curbside pickup starting Friday. In order to do so, they are being asked to develop contactless payment procedures, have hand sanitizer available for employees and customers, ensure employees have proper protective gear, and ask employees to deliver goods to customers' cars when possible. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

Silver Dollar Saloon has been closed to diners, only offering take-out and delivery, since March 18th. Owner Joe Ferrie had laid off 23 employees. Sutter and Yuba counties, both north of Sacramento, are allowing businesses and restaurants to reopen, defying Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus pandemic. item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Where's the beef? In California, it is still available, but meat eaters might need to settle for cuts other than prime steaks. The industry is dealing with production backups caused by coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Where's the beef? In California, it is still available, but meat eaters might need to settle for cuts other than prime steaks. The industry is dealing with production backups caused by coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: California's livestock industry is urging consumers to try out cuts of beef other than prime steaks, like these seen in a Jan. 18, 2010 file photo. The coronavirus pandemic has created bottlenecks in processing plants, so meat eaters might need to get their fix with unusual cuts.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday April 14, 2020 file photo,, California Gov. Gavin Newsom speaks during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. Newsom announced Friday, April 24 that taxpayers will pay restaurants to make meals for millions of California's seniors during the coronavirus pandemic, an initiative that could pump billions of dollars into a devastated industry. California governments scrambled to set up programs to have three meals delivered to seniors each day amid the coronavirus crisis, but it wasn't clear when deliveries would start going out the door. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli,File)

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, April 14, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. On a near daily basis since outlining his criteria for someday easing stay-at-home orders, Newsom, who recently allowed scheduled surgeries to resume, has warned Californians that, while he understands their desires to get back to work and a sense of normalcy, lifting the orders too soon could be a public health mistake. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)
